H0.text: Chemical to thermal is the energy conversion that occurs when the fuel in a gasoline engine is burned.

H1.text: Potential energy is converted to nuclear energy when the fuel in a gasoline engine is burned.

H2.text: Thermal to potential is the energy conversion that occurs when the fuel in a gasoline engine is burned.

H3.text: Electrical to kinetic is the energy conversion that occurs when the fuel in a gasoline engine is burned.

A4.text: Once ignited and burnt, the combustion products—hot gases—have more available thermal energy than the original compressed fuel-air mixture (which had higher chemical energy).

A5.text: All internal combustion engines depend on combustion of a chemical fuel, typically with oxygen from the air (though it is possible to inject nitrous oxide to do more of the same thing and gain a power boost).
